10.text:
Caroline Pegum:– The Understanding British
Portraits network is a network for those with

14.text:
a professional engagement with portraiture,
such as curators, scholars, academics, conservators,

20.text:
and our museum-based learning colleagues.
At the network, we offer our members a range

25.text:
of events throughout the year. We’re at
Woburn Abbey today for a study day with our

32.text:
members, to examine in-depth with the staff
here the very rich portrait collection owned

37.text:
by the Duke and Duchess of Bedford.
Lucy Howgego:– Today is part of a vision

41.text:
that I had of creating study days at Woburn,
for both Woburn to learn more about its collection

48.text:
by inviting professionals in, and also to
give them the opportunity to see the collection,

53.text:
make it more accessible to them.
Matthew Hirst:– I had a particularly interesting

63.text:
conversation on the Grand Staircase around
the two portraits of the sons of the second

68.text:
earl. In the background there are, sort of,
images of gardens and seascapes and so on,

74.text:
and one of the gentlemen has some snakes near
his hand, which are holding a sort of motto,

81.text:
and we simply don’t understand them. Hopefully,
now that they’ve seen those, they might

85.text:
go away, think about it, and come back to
us with some solutions.

89.text:
Dr Stephen Lloyd:– The Gallery is really
a tremendous experience, with this outstanding

95.text:
collection of 16th and 17th century English
/ British portraits in oils.

100.text:
Karen Hearn:– The collection at Woburn is
a real centre of excellence for a very important

106.text:
late-16th/ early-17th century portrait painter
called Marcus Gheeraerts the Younger. The

112.text:
full length female portrait in the long gallery
is one of his rare signed works, and it’s

116.text:
signed on the chair, and it’s incredibly
difficult to see. And as a member of the public

122.text:
just going through, one wouldn’t possibly
have the opportunity to find it. So, we had

128.text:
a chance to find it on a day like this when
we were looking at it, and it’s very helpful,

133.text:
because it tells us what Gheeraerts’s style
was like at that comparatively late period

139.text:
in his career.
Catharine MacLeod:– The portrait of John

144.text:
Kennedy, which may be by Marcus Gheeraerts
the Younger, the appearance of the man is

148.text:
very similar to a man called Grey Brydges,
Lord Chandos, who was a member of the same

154.text:
family. It seems possible that the portrait
has been wrongly identified as John Kennedy,

160.text:
and in fact, was John Kennedy’s brother-in-law.
Dr Charlotte Bolland:– I was really interested

169.text:
to come to Woburn, because the amazing collection
of 16th century portraits. And I’ve been

173.text:
involved in a research project, looking at
the Armada portrait of Elizabeth I. And it

177.text:
was really exciting to have the opportunity
to talk to a, kind of, group of people about

180.text:
the research that we’ve been doing, to hear
their, kind of, feedback and comments. Yes,

184.text:
the X-ray image gives idea of, kind of, what’s
been slightly lost through the modelling in

190.text:
the face, so where now it’s this incredibly,
kind of, mask-like finish, actually you can

194.text:
see in the X-ray that there is real texture
in the flesh painting. It was much more modelled

199.text:
and worked out, and it’s just because we
lost those final layers now.

203.text:
Alexandra Gent:– My interest in the collection
at Woburn is the paintings by Sir Joshua Reynolds,

209.text:
who… Which is the artist that I’m most
interested in. And there’s a really amazing

213.text:
collection here of family paintings that were
painted in the earlier part of Reynolds’s

218.text:
career. For me, it was just really great to
see the portraits all framed together in the

224.text:
same style of frame, which I wasn’t expecting.
And also, to see that some of the canvases

228.text:
had been enlarged and made into bigger paintings
from the original portraits. It’s just been

234.text:
really interesting for me to walk around the
collection with people that are experts in

237.text:
different areas, and I’ve learnt so much
from hearing from what other people have had

241.text:
to say about paintings that interested them.
Stephen Lloyd:– I’ve really been able

245.text:
to develop conversations which are both on
the technical level, conservation, display,

250.text:
framing…
Victoria Poulton:– Yes, everyone got involved

254.text:
and, sort of, started pitching in different
ideas, and something… Really interesting

258.text:
things came to light.
Matthew Hirst:– We’ve got various specialists

262.text:
together, unusually, you know, in one room.
You very rarely find that, except at some

266.text:
great big conference. So, to have the privilege
of them coming to Woburn, onto our home turf,
